prescan.instruction: Before analyzing visual content, establish perceptual context:
prescan.step: View the entire image without focusing on details. What is the overall impression?
Identify the most salient element - what demands attention first through size, color, contrast, or position?
Map the visual hierarchy: primary focal point → secondary elements → supporting details → background.
Note spatial organization: is content centered, asymmetric, grid-based, or organic?
Identify relationships between visual elements through proximity and alignment.

primary.guidance: Identify what draws the eye first and why: - High contrast against background - Largest element in the composition - Brightest or most saturated color - Central or golden-ratio positioning - Isolated element with surrounding whitespace Report saliency hierarchy in your analysis.

Clearly distinguish: - FIGURE: Primary visual content meant to convey information - GROUND: Background, decorative elements, framing devices Some elements may be ambiguous - note when figure/ground relationship is unclear or intentionally blurred.

Identify visual groups formed by spatial proximity: - Elements clustered together share semantic relationship - Whitespace creates boundaries between groups - Alignment creates implicit groupings even without proximity Report these groupings as part of your visual analysis.

secondary.guidance: Note patterns of visual consistency: - Color coding that links related elements - Shape repetition indicating category membership - Size consistency suggesting equal importance

visual_hierarchy_detection.level: Largest, boldest, highest contrast, most central - the main subject.
Supporting elements that complement the primary - moderate visual weight.
Details, labels, annotations - smallest visual weight.
Ground elements, decorative features, framing - not primary content.

relationship_identification.relationship: One element visually contains another (frame around image).
Elements side-by-side or stacked suggest comparison or sequence.
Lines, arrows, or visual bridges link elements.
Overlapping elements suggest layering or emphasis.

validation.check: Did you identify the correct visual hierarchy based on saliency cues?
Are figure/ground distinctions clear and accurate?
Did you capture spatial groupings and their implied relationships?
Does your analysis reflect what a human viewer would perceive as important?
Are visual relationships (containment, adjacency, connection) accurately described?
